Global sea ice dropped more than 4 million km2 below average, a development the WMO calls “an unprecedented anomaly.”

title: Are You Too Connected?
post_description: I’ve only recently joined the ranks of the billions of people with smartphones, and I quickly understood why these miraculous devices have become so popular. As long as I’ve got my phone, I have a camera ready to snap a shot of any adorable moment in my kids’ day – and text it to their grateful grandparents. I can get directions when I’m lost, or look up the answer to virtually any question.

title: Are Non-toxic Art Supplies Important for Your Health?
post_description: Whether you are a fine artist, a crafter, a parent, or a dabbler, you have probably experienced the highs and lows of an art project. But while it would be nice to create something that stands the test of time, let's hope doing art won't shorten your life or the life of the planet. To that end, it's good to be aware of the potential dangers of everyday art supplies and learn more about their alternatives.

title: 5 Amazing Herbal Teas to Help You Beat the Flu
post_description: Just when you think you've escaped, the flu can hit you like a brick. But before you run to the doctor or send your significant other to the store to wander haplessly through the aisles, remember: antibiotics don't work for viruses and most over-the-counter medications only treat the symptoms.

title: The 10 Best Reasons to Get Outside this Winter
post_description: The winters in Minnesota can be long and really cold, so appreciating the season can take some effort. To be honest, I could do without the -20 windchills and icy sidewalks that make getting anywhere a challenge. Plus, around here winter drags on for up to 6 months, so I don’t always get as much time outside as I’d like.

title: Walking: The Cure for What Ails You
post_description: The winter cold is setting in, the last of the holiday cheer is fading away, and in many parts of the country, there are more grey days than sunny ones. Your first instinct is to curl up with a good book and a warm cup of tea, but what you really need is a brisk walk. Rain or shine, a walk has some miraculous healing properties that even modern medicine can't rival.

title: 4 Simple Ways to Slow Down for the New Year
post_description: With presents to wrap, parties to throw, and a house to decorate, the holiday season can be exceptionally hectic. As delightful as all these parties and events are, having too much on our schedules can leave us feeling drained and less jolly than we might like, especially by the time the New Year rolls around. Having busy schedules can also prevent us from enjoying these events in the first place.

title: Supercharge Your Meals With Dehydrated Greens
post_description: You’ve seen them in health food stores stocking shelves for winter: ‘powdered greens’ supplements replete with a long list of healthful ingredients guaranteed to boost your immunity, repair free radical damage, and improve overall mood and vitality.

title: Getting PCBs Out of Our Schools
post_description: Earlier this month, Senator Edward Markey (D-Mass.), America Unites for Kids, and the Environmental Working Group released reports about PCBs in school buildings across the United States. Their findings were based on research conducted by Harvard researcher Dr. Robert Herrick and revealed that up to 14 million students in the U.S. may be exposed to unsafe levels of PCBs.

title: Veganism, Sustainability, and Punk Rock: Eartheasy Speaks with Joshua Ploeg
post_description: When you think of combining music with food, what comes to mind?  Wine and cheese before the symphony?  Margaritas, tacos, and hot Latin jazz?  How about soymilk chai, vegan fare and punk rock?  Hmmm.  Perhaps not the most common of pairings.

title: Is Food Packaging Safe?
post_description: Many of us choose organic in order to avoid exposure to chemicals. But even our organic cheese and beans come in packaging that may leach chemicals into our pesticide-free food. What’s a health enthusiast to do?

title: Grow Your Own Medicine
post_description: With the explosion of interest in alternative medicine and increasing numbers of resources available online, it’s easier than ever to dabble in using herbals to support health and treat or prevent common ailments, from headaches and colds to insomnia and anxiety.

title: The Health Benefits of Getting Dirty
post_description: You may have read about the myriad ways gardening supports good health, providing gentle exercise, vitamin D, and stress-busting contact with nature. It turns out that some of the most powerful health benefits of gardening may come from our contact with the soil itself.

title: Grow Your Own Herbal Teas!
post_description: “There is tea, and then there is tea,” my grandmother used to say when she was drinking one of the many herbal concoctions I used to serve her during my university days. Raised from proud British stock, she only ever considered one beverage worthy of the moniker tea, and that was the one brewed from the plant Camellia sinensis. Her tea came in tins or boxes, and was first rolled, oxidized, and fermented to a dark chocolate brown before finding its way across oceans and into her pot.

title: Organic Meat and Milk Contain More Omega-3s
post_description: Whether organically-raised foods are nutritionally superior has been a matter of debate for some time. While some studies have shown, for instance, that the concentration of nutrients in organic fruits and vegetables is higher than in their conventionally-grown counterparts, other studies have found otherwise. Two new meta-analyses focusing on organic milk and meat found that organic versions of these foods do in fact differ from conventional ones.

title: The Toxic Stuff of Daily Life
post_description: In May of last year, a document known as the Madrid Statement warned of the dangers of a class of common chemicals called poly- and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs), which are used in everything from water-repellant clothing to the lining of pizza boxes. Over 200 scientists registered their concern about the increasing amounts of these “highly persistent” compounds, which are found in the tissue and fluids of humans and animals worldwide.

title: Can Vegan Cheese Help Shrink Your Foodprint?
post_description: In researching the climate impact of food, I was dismayed to learn that though we ate very little meat (good climate move), the amount of cheese my family consumed was not so climate-friendly. With greater greenhouse gas emissions than fish, poultry, or pork, the cheese in our diets significantly upped the emissions of our otherwise relatively low-carbon lives.

title: In Defense of Wheat
post_description: Confused about bread and its place in your life? You’re not alone. More than 20% of Americans are trying to avoid gluten, though their reasons range from the relatively uncommon diagnosis of Celiac Disease, to a wide range of ambiguous health symptoms, to a vague media-generated sense that “gluten-free” means healthier.

title: How to Drink Water After Flint
post_description: Water.  It’s in our soup, in our coffee, in our bathtubs and our baby bottles.  When it’s clean and abundant, we take it for granted.  Even if you’ve never been to Michigan, you’re probably feeling for the people of Flint.  Their betrayal hits hard.  Americans are raised to feel uncommonly safe and protected.  Like most affluent “first world” nations, our government agencies and public utilities are assumed to be competent, transparent, and trustworthy.

title: Zika Virus 'Spreading Explosively,' What You Need to Know
post_description: What is Zika? The Zika virus was discovered decades ago in the Zika forest of Uganda, and because symptoms of infection are typically mild – 80% of those infected don’t even have symptoms – researchers have not paid much attention to it. Carried by mosquitoes, Zika recently migrated to the Americas, where populations have not built up immunity, allowing it to spread quickly.

title: Can Happiness Save the World? Self-Help in Urgent Times
post_description: After rising to prominence with No Impact Man, a chronicle of his year-long experiment to live as greenly as possible in New York City, writer Colin Beavan says he’s figured out how to “have it all”: a comfortable, fun life AND the satisfaction of “doing good” for the planet. With his recent book How to Be Alive, he’s ready to start a movement of “lifequesters” who reject “standard life approaches” in favor of finding their own truth.

title: Should We Be Eating Insects?
post_description: Sometimes solutions to the world’s toughest problems are right under our noses—or that’s what innovators from Europe and North America seem to be discovering in their hunt for global food security. In recent years, impending protein shortages and the lack of sustainable food production models have led more than one innovator to the practice of entomophagy, otherwise known as eating insects. Could they</br> be onto something?

title: Is Radon an Unseen Hazard in Your Home?
post_description: Though you can’t see, smell, hear, or feel it, radon nonetheless poses a significant risk to human health. This naturally occurring radioactive gas comes from uranium, found in nearly all soils, and infiltrates our homes through cracks in foundations. Radon can become trapped in our houses and build to unhealthy levels if not remediated.

title: How to Reduce Lead Hazards in Your Home
post_description: Lead contamination can seem like a problem we solved long ago, when we wisely outlawed lead in gasoline and paint and stopped using lead pipes. However, like many widely used industrial materials, lead is pretty persistent in the environment and remains a danger if you don’t take precautions. Why should lead merit your attention? Even at low levels, lead can have significant neurological effects.

title: Allergens in Natural Beauty Products
post_description: Women want to be beautiful.  The cosmetic market is saturated with products that promise to make us look younger and more radiant, yet many of these assurances of beauty also come with the reality of harsh chemicals from a test tube.  Taking this into consideration, it is easy to understand why women often look toward natural beauty products as a safer alternative.

title: Stop Killing the Microbes that Keep Us Healthy: 5 Strategies
post_description: It’s a perspective shift.  As living creatures, we see ourselves members of a large ecosystem, however, we each also contain an ecosystem.  Our bodies each host more than 100 trillion microbes, going about their daily business on every inch of our skin and much of our insides.  These minuscule life forms outnumber our own cells by about 10 to 1, which is a good argument to begin using the royal “We” to refer to oneself.

title: Healing Gardens
post_description: “There is new life in the soil for every man. There is healing in the trees for tired minds and for our overburdened spirit, there is strength in the hills, if only we lift up our eyes. Remember that nature is your great restorer.” Calvin Coolidge

title: Systemic Pesticides and Food Health
post_description: When, exactly, did a bowl of grapes on a buffet table become cause for suspicion, rather than delight?  Increasingly, we’re not afraid to ask “are those organic?” before taking a bite.  If the answer is no, we may pass on to the next item.

title: Natural Remedies for Winter Depression (Seasonal Affective Disorder)
post_description: As daylight hours wane and the northern hemisphere tilts away from the sun, plants and animals make their instinctual seasonal preparations.  Biological changes transform the landscape: deciduous trees shed leaves to conserve energy and enter dormancy; certain birds emerge in new seasonally-appropriate plumage, while others migrate southward.

title: 10 Steps to Make (And Keep) an Effective New Year's Resolution
post_description: Out with the old, in with the new!  The calendar year turns, and all around the world we reflect upon the past twelve months and make wishes about our upcoming “trip around the sun”.  A new year, like a birthday, can startle us with the tangible passing of time: our days are limited and precious.

title: 11 Common Foods to Avoid During Pregnancy
post_description: At your very first prenatal visit, you may be given lists of anxiety-inducing “don’ts” from your well-meaning medical provider.  Don’t handle cat litter — it can carry toxoplasmosis.  Don’t eat undercooked eggs to avoid salmonella, and stay away from brie and other soft cheeses which have been linked to listeria.

title: Can Dementia be Prevented by Diet and Lifestyle?
post_description: As we grow older, many of us begin losing sleep over the looming possibility of developing Alzheimer’s or other forms of dementia.  Ironically, both sleep problems and anxiety increase our risk profile for developing these conditions. Especially if we’ve cared for a parent or other relative with dementia, we want to feel like we have the power to change our own fate.

title: How to Choose Earth-Friendly Edible Oils
post_description: Like any food product, there are oils that are produced more sustainably than others, and those that are better for our health. There is usually a lot of processing involved in the production of oils before they reach your kitchen, from where the oils come from, to how it is metabolized in our bodies, to where and how long to store it, </br>and oh yes, how it tastes!

title: Teaching Your Child to Love Vegetables
post_description: In Dr. Seuss’s Green Eggs and Ham, cajoling your kids with every outlandish trick you can muster: “Would you eat them in a box? Would you eat them with a fox?” In the name of the elusive “balanced diet”, we’ve all engaged in parenting strategies we’d rather not confess. Nowhere else are the power-struggles of the parent/child relationship laid so bare.

title: How to Remove Fluoride from Water
post_description: In 1945, Grand Rapids, Michigan became the first US city to fluoridate the public water supply.  The idea quickly caught on, and the controversy began soon after: in growing numbers, a vocal minority has raised concerns about fluoride’s role in a broad range of health problems.

title: How to Use Nettles with Your Springtime Cooking
post_description: Nettles have been on earth longer than humans—we just forgot about them for a few generations.  A century ago, rural cooks prized wild plants.  Foraging was a daily domestic routine, a tradition and a necessity.

title: Evidence Grows Linking Autism with Pollution
post_description: For years, parents have traded stories online, seeking answers about their child’s mysterious disability.  This month, a newly published analysis shows the strongest correlation yet between autism and prenatal exposure to pollution.  Other smaller studies previously suggested a connection, but science is cautious to confirm findings until the results can be repeated in larger-scale projects.

title: 8 Common Products Expecting Moms Should Avoid
post_description: A pregnant woman gets plenty of well-meaning advice — everyone in the check-out line offers an opinion about her diet, her weight, and which parenting philosophy she should read up on.  But it’s easy to overlook some items considered “necessities” of daily life, though investigating their ingredients reveals cause for unease.

title: After Fukushima - Is It Safe to Eat Pacific Seafood?
post_description: Following the catastrophic failure of the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear plant on March 11, 2011, many of us found another reason to lose sleep.  Nearly three years later, news of the unfolding disaster alternately overwhelms us and falls strangely silent.  Conflicting opinions, theories, and “facts” each offer to enlighten, reassure, or terrify.

title: How to Make a Winter Soup to Boost Your Immune System
post_description: Making soup is a healing practice.  It starts with the simple intention to nourish and nurture ourselves and our loved ones.  This soup can come together in an hour, but its effect on the body and soul are a world away from the quick-fixes of take-out food or frozen entrees.

title: FDA to Phase Out Trans Fats in Processed Foods
post_description: The Food and Drug Administration initiated a process today which will most likely result in the banning of trans fats in all food products sold in the US. For over a decade, scientific consensus has been building over the dangers of trans fats which are used to improve the taste and texture of many processed food products, and to increase product shelf life. The artery-clogging properties of trans fats have been shown to increase levels of LDL “bad” cholesterol, while lowering levels of HDL “good” cholesterol.

title: Eight Easy-To-Find Superfoods
post_description: You’ve no doubt witnessed the “superfood” trend sweeping across the health world. From Peruvian maca maca fruit to Chinese hemp seeds to Tibetan gogi berries, these crazy and exotic compounds are currently the darling of magazines and food blogs everywhere.

title: Smart Seafood Choices: How to be an Informed Seafood Consumer
post_description: Doctors recommend fish over beef, mutton and pork for healthy human protein consumption. Yet, with global warming and ocean acidification, can the oceans sustain more harvesting of fish? Seafood plays an important role in a balanced diet. High in Omega-3s, which boost immunity and reduce the risk of heart disease, stroke, cancer and other ailments, seafood is especially important for pregnant and nursing women and young children.

title: Certified Organic: What Does It Mean?
post_description: My friend Ruth couldn’t come to sauna the other night. She said she had food poisoning from the nitrates in the bacon she had eaten earlier in the day. I looked up nitrates and learned that sodium nitrate and sodium nitrite are used to keep red meat looking red, and with limited scientific proof, to inhibit botulism. The nitrates wouldn’t have been in the bacon had it been certified organic.

title: Cancer-causing chemical found in drinking water of 31 U.S. cities
post_description: Study results released today by the Environmental Working Group (EWG) report that hexavalent chromium, the cancer-causing chemical made famous by the film “Erin Brockovich,” has been detected in the tap water of 31 of the 35 U.S. cities tested.

title: 4 Tips for Safe, Effective Sunscreen Use
post_description: It seems the more research that goes into the safety and effectiveness of sunscreens, the more confusing it is for consumers to use these formulations with confidence.

title: Link Found Between Air Pollution and Childhood Obesity
post_description: The underlying causes of obesity in the US have long been attributed to poor diet and lack of exercise, but the results of a recent study at Columbia University indicate that air pollution also contributes to obesity in children. Children born to women who were exposed to higher levels of certain air pollutants during pregnancy were nearly twice as likely to become obese by age 5 than children of mothers with lower levels of exposure.

title: “Non-Toxic” Nail Polishes Found to Contain Toxins
post_description: I don’t wear nail polish, it simply doesn’t appeal to me. And fancy nails don’t go with gardening, which does appeal to me. But every time I go to Sacramento to visit my mom and sister, the first thing they do is invite me to the local nail salon to get a manicure and pedicure. I’m a country girl coming to town and they see some rough edges that need smoothing. I realize they want to give me a treat, so I go along</br> with the program.

title: Are Children Spending Enough Time Outdoors?
post_description: “In my 40+ years of observing families, the single biggest change I have seen is that children are not outside playing like they used to,” said Nell Trayhill, a retired family therapist from South Carolina. Standing behind me on line at an airport ticket counter last month, Mrs. Trayhill seemed happy to have my ear.

title: Swallowing Our Pride
post_description: Extremes of achievement have always fascinated us. The Guinness Book of Records has made a fortune documenting the outer boundaries of human experience with the implicit message that competition brings out the best in all of us, unlocking our pent up potential. While many of the Guinness records are indeed worthy acknowledgements of human accomplishment, some are testament to low points in the human experience.

title: Microscopic Plastic Particles May Be Entering Food Chain
post_description: Plastic particles less than 1mm, defined as ‘microplastics’, have been steadily accumulating in marine environments across the globe. Studies of shoreline debris at 18 different locations worldwide have identified small, fibrous particles of plastic which are washed up on beaches, embedded in sediments and even found in cell tissues of marine organisms.

title: Are You Feeding Your Kids Twinkies For Breakfast?
post_description: We all know it’s the sugar in children’s cereals that makes them popular. And cereal makers, more than anyone, are aware of the singular appeal of sugar amid the myriad of ingredients in today’s breakfast cereals. Parents may indulge their children with sugary cereals from time to time, but most parents would forbid a breakfast diet of Twinkies or chocolate chip cookies.

title: BPA Levels Spike with Canned Soup
post_description: Surprising results from a recent study at the Harvard School of Public Health have shown that volunteers who consumed one serving of canned soup a day for five days had a more than 1,200 percent increase in urinary BPA (Bisphenol A) over people who consumed fresh soup for the same period. The authors say their study is one of the few to measure human BPA levels after consuming</br> canned products.

title: Why TV for Children Under Two is a Bad Idea
post_description: Researchers are using the scientific approach to establish what many parents know intuitively – children under two years of age should not be watching TV.

title: The Healing Power of a Walk in the Woods
post_description: For over 20 years, I walked to work each morning along a winding trail through a forest of giant cedar and fir trees, my mind usually preoccupied with the challenges of helping run</br> a small woodworking business.

title: 7 Easy Ways to Reduce Your Exposure to Formaldehyde
post_description: On June 10, 2011, the National Toxicology Program released its 12th Report on Carcinogens, which added formaldehyde to its list of carcinogens, and said it is found in ‘worrisome quantities’ in plywood, particle board, mortuaries and hair salons.

title: WHO: Cell Phone Emissions May Cause Cancer
post_description: Cell phones have become such an integral part of our daily lives that it’s natural to want to dismiss warning of potential health hazards associated with their use. But a new advisory issued from the World Health Organization may cause us to reconsider how we use cell phones, and whether these devices should be used</br> at all by young people.

title: Prenatal Pesticide Exposure Linked to Lower IQs in Children
post_description: Pregnant women, while still encouraged to eat fruit and vegetables as part of a healthy diet, should wash produce thoroughly before eating, or better yet, buy organic produce. This advice comes in the wake of three new studies linking prenatal exposure to pesticides with lower IQs in children. Pesticides classified as organophosphates are primarily used to treat agricultural crops, and to a lesser extent can be found in yard and garden pest control products.

title: 5 Tips to Reduce Your Exposure to BPA and Other Hormone Disrupting Chemicals in Your Diet
post_description: Adults and children can reduce their exposure to hormone-disrupting chemicals, including bisphenol-A (BPA), by eating more fruits and vegetables and less food from plastic containers and metal cans, according to a recent study. A group of 20 San Francisco residents had 66% less BPA in their urine after spending three days on a diet of fresh, organic and unpackaged food, scientists found.

title: 6 Tips for Safer Cell Phone Use
post_description: As developments in cell phone technology leap forward, the studies of potential health impacts associated with cell phone use present confusing and inconclusive results.

title: Cadmium in Kids’ Jewelry May Pose Poison Risk
post_description: Editor’s Note: I fail to understand why parents put jewelry on babies, or give toy jewelry to young children. Children don’t need jewelry to enhance their natural beauty. And indulging a young child with cheap trinkets introduces them to the concept of consumerism as a false standard of beauty and status.

title: Eco-impact of wild seafood less than that of poultry, beef
post_description: At a recent Seafood Summit in Vancouver, B.C., Professor Ray Hilborn, Ph.D., a world-famous fisheries researcher from the University of Washington’s School of Aquatic and Fishery Sciences, described his encouraging conclusions about the relative ecological impacts of land-based food production versus acquisition of edible protein and fats from wild seafood.

title: 7 Ways to Wean your Child off Video Games
post_description: The appeal of today’s ubiquitous video games is based on sound value: the games are fun, the action is fast, the challenges are inviting. Yet when kids and teens spend time in front of small screens – whether it’s the TV, computer or hand-held games – it takes away from the time they could spend playing sport, learning other skills</br> or enjoying active play.

title: Is Gulf Coast Seafood Safe to Eat?
post_description: Gulf residents and seafood industry workers can breathe a collective sigh of relief with the recent reopening of approximately 3,000 square miles of the Gulf to shrimp and fish harvesting.

title: US Legislation Proposes Chemical Safety Reform in Consumer Products
post_description: Manufacturers have created products for every aspect of our modern lifestyles, but the chemicals in some of these products may pose health risks to ourselves and our families. From cell phones, iPods and computers, to household cleaners and furnishings, children’s toys, paints, and many common items we use every day, it is assumed that someone has ensured the safety of their chemical components. But such is not the case.

title: Prenatal Pesticide Exposure May Raise Risk of ADHD in Children
post_description: Researchers have noted a link between prenatal exposure to organophosphate pesticides and attention disorders in children. In a study reported in a recent edition of Environmental Health Perspectives, the effects of prenatal pesticide exposure in children were not significant at the age of 3, but became apparent at age 5.

title: Bottled Teas Low in Health Benefits
post_description: Drinking green or black tea offers a range of health benefits, but health-conscious consumers may not be getting similar benefits from bottled tea drinks. Researchers reported at the National Meeting of the American Chemical Society that many bottled teas contain almost no antioxidants - polyphenols from tea.

title: 7 Principles of a Climate-Friendly Diet
post_description: The link between climate change and the food we eat is direct, critical, and must be acknowledged if we are to make progress in the global fight against climate change. In her groundbreaking book, Diet for a Hot Planet, Anna Lappé makes a convincing case that the entire global food chain may account for roughly one third of what’s heating our planet.

title: The Salmonella Outbreak: Are Free-Range, Organic Eggs Safer?
post_description: As the government oversees a recall of over 500 million eggs due to a salmonella scare, consumers are wondering which eggs are safe and which are best to avoid. Eggs marketed as “free range,” “cage free,” and “organic” may provide a safer alternative, but understanding these terms will help the consumer make a more informed choice.

title: 6 Ways to Reduce Your Exposure to Pesticides
post_description: Pesticides are designed to control the nuisance and damage caused by pests, and have contributed to reducing disease and increasing food production worldwide. But the availability and widespread use of pesticides also has the potential to pose unexpected risks, both directly and indirectly, to our health.

title: Pesticide Exposure May Increase Risk of ADHD in Children
post_description: A study recently reported in the journal Pediatrics draws a link between exposure to a type of pesticide residue found on commercially grown produce and the incidence of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children. Children exposed to higher levels of pesticides known as organophosphates could have a higher risk of ADHD.

title: Nettle Tea – How to Make a Natural Spring Tonic
post_description: Nettle tea is springtime’s natural elixir. One of the earliest green plants to emerge each spring, nettles can be easily brewed into a tea which has healthful, restorative benefits which boost the immune system and awaken the body to spring.

title: Wet Cleaning vs. Dry Cleaning
post_description: PERC is dangerous to our environment, to animals, to adults and to children. We can be exposed to PERC as easily as through the air we breathe and the water we drink.

title: Formaldehyde Link to Leukemia Confirmed: How to Limit Exposure in the Home
post_description: In October 2009, 23 scientists from 6 countries met at the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) to reassess the carcinogenicity of a number of chemical compounds previously classified as carcinogenic to humans.

title: Making Your Own Apple Juice
post_description: As anyone who has fruit trees knows, a lot of fruit goes to waste. Woodpecker holes, worm holes, bug damage and bruises occur on a considerable portion of the harvest. Imperfect fruit will not last in storage and can ruin other fruit it is stored with. A great way to avoid this waste is to make your own juice.

title: Vermiculite and Asbestos: How to Minimize the Risks
post_description: When we hear the word "asbestos" we often think back on the controversy of the late 1970's when it became common knowledge that asbestos was indeed a human health hazard. Since then, many steps have been taken to remove asbestos from buildings and commercial products in an effort to reduce human exposure to this mineral.

title: Healthy Cookware
post_description: There are potential risks in some cookware materials. Aluminum and Teflon-lined pots, pans and bakeware are safest when kept in good condition and used properly. Stainless steel, enameled or well-seasoned cast iron and porcelain cookware are best.

title: What is Healthy for the Person is Healthy for the Planet
post_description:
I often enjoy a long walk through our forests and mountains. And on each journey I absorb a little more of that infinite ocean of wisdom which pervades the natural world. "Our" forests and mountains because we are part of nature, something most of us forget most of the time. A people-constructed environment of computers, automobiles and office towers are the realities which usually must
be accommodated.

title: Bird-safe Painting Tips
post_description: Pet birds can be hard on cages, often chewing, scratching or wearing the paint. They can ingest flakes of paint which can be harmful to their health. Pet birds can also be sensitive to fumes from new paint.

title: Healthy Lawns, Healthy Lungs?
post_description: Now that spring is in the air, the fancy of many home owners turns to lawn care. But this annual ritual doesn't bring much joy to Dr. June Irwin, one of the most outspoken members of the Canadian medical profession on the subject of pesticides in urban areas.

title: Last Child in the Woods
post_description: Children are spending less time outside than ever before. In this groundbreaking book, child advocate Richard Louv examines the implications of nature-free childhoods and what they mean for the future of our children and humanity.

title: Climate Change: What You Can Do About It
post_description: The Union of Concerned Scientists, a group of over two thousand scientists, has concluded that global warming is beyond dispute, and already changing our climate.

title: Ocean Plastic Pollution: Here’s How You Can Help
post_description: Every year, 8 million metric tons of plastic enter the world’s oceans. Much of that comes from single-use plastic items like straws, plastic bags, and plastic bottles, used for a matter of minutes before becoming permanent sources of pollution.

title: Scientists Reveal Why BPA Plastic Still Isn’t Safe
post_description: The harmful effects of BPA plastic are widely discussed, yet the US Food and Drug Administration maintains the chemical is safe in low doses. Now a landmark study reveals reasons for the mixed messages—and what you can do to safeguard your family’s health.

title: Can De-Extinction Save Our Planet? An Interview with Britt Wray
post_description: The word “de-extinction” conjures up visions of dinosaur theme parks populated with predators never meant to roam the earth again, but the reality is a far cry from Hollywood scaremongering.

title: This Artists’ Ink is Made From Air Pollution
post_description: Imagine, if you will, an art tool that creates the most beautiful, satisfying clean line with an indelible super black color. Any artist would be interested already, but that’s not all. Imagine that this tool is also a sophisticated way of harvesting pollution from the air. Is your mind blown yet?

title: 5 Amazing Inventions For a Thirsty Planet
post_description: As the earth’s population continues to climb, pressure on the world’s finite amounts of drinkable water has increased markedly. UN Water, the United Nations’ water agency, reports that 40% of the global population already deals with water scarcity. By 2025, the agency predicts that two-thirds of people worldwide may</br> live in “water-stressed conditions.”

title: Scientists Reveal How Smartphones Make Us Dumber
post_description: A recent study has concluded that just because you put your phone in your pocket on vibrate, doesn’t mean it isn’t distracting you. In fact, turning your phone off to avoid distraction may be futile because your brain still knows it’s there.

title: Electric Car Traveling 10,000 Miles in Mongol Car Rally
post_description: While some people wonder if an electric vehicle will get them across their state in good time, Chris Ramsey of Plug-in Adventures is embracing the technology by driving 10,000 miles in his Nissan Leaf.

title: Scientists Found Lead in Baby Food. Is it Time to Make Your Own?
post_description: We want our babies to have the best start in life and do everything we can to ensure their health and safety. We read piles of baby books, eat carefully during pregnancy, and buy non-toxic baby gear. Unfortunately, many threats to our children’s health lurk in places we least suspect, even in baby food.

title: What Can Listening to Nature Teach Us?
post_description: Over increasingly large areas of the United States, spring now comes unheralded by the return of the birds. The early mornings are strangely silent where once they were filled with</br> the beauty of bird song.  – Rachel Carson, Silent Spring

title: Germany is Proving Renewable Energy Can Power a Country
post_description: The Energiewende plan envisions a non-nuclear Germany that cuts its carbon emissions by 80% by 2050. As lofty a goal as this may be, the plan is on pace to meet and even exceed benchmarks. Even though not everyone is on board, and some claim the Energiewende is overzealous and could strangle business, progress is well underway.

title: Cutting the Climate Impact of Beef
post_description: Global meat consumption has risen rapidly in recent decades, with profound effects on our climate. Carbon-storing forests have been cleared to make pasture for cattle, while growing grain to feed them has contributed additional climate-warming emissions. Then there’s what the cows themselves add to the climate problem: They produce a great deal of methane, a gas with roughly 30 times the global warming potential of carbon dioxide.

title: The Regenerative Farming Revolution: Eartheasy Speaks With Producer Lisa Heenan
post_description: When Joel Salatin's parents bought their farm, the land was worn out, the soil was disappearing, and much of it was bare rock. With dreams of building a self-reliant lifestyle, they went to the agricultural extension and were told to use chemicals and other 'traditional' strategies. Instead, they did the opposite, using cows to kick start the natural process of grazing to restart the biomass of the land.

title: EPA Rolls Back Plans to Ban Harmful Pesticide
post_description: With the current US administration shifting government focus away from environmental issues, one hazard that has been put on the backburner is chlorpyrifos, a common pesticide used in agriculture and on turf in the United States. Although the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) had been working on banning the chemical outright, the agency has since discarded its plans.

title: Innovative Swedish Mall Embraces the Circular Economy
post_description: Sometimes a new idea makes so much sense, it’s hard to understand why no one thought of it before. That’s the case with ReTuna, the shopping mall located in Eskilstuna, Sweden, that requires all its retailers to sell used and repurposed goods. But ReTuna isn’t just a haven of thrift. The mall also acts as a community education hub and recycling center, where residents of the municipality can drop off their recycling and donations for stores to resell or use to create new items with an invigorated purpose.

title: Let Them Eat Dirt: Eartheasy Speaks with B. Brett Finlay
post_description: Ah, the good old days. Remember when you played outside all day and didn’t come back to the house until your mother called for you? And even then, you only came in begrudgingly? You washed your hands with plain soap and water. You slid into your chair at the dinner table with dirt smudges on your clothes and knees and nobody panicked about that.  Maybe you ate your meal without worrying about gluten or peanuts, and you didn’t have asthma or allergies.

title: What Should We Do With All That Carbon in the Atmosphere?
post_description: Our earth has permanently crossed a dangerous threshold. Humans continue to burn fossil fuels regardless of the consequences, with the result that our atmosphere now contains 400 parts per million (ppm) of carbon dioxide (CO2). Unfortunately, 350 ppm was the last safe level of atmospheric CO2.

title: Can Technology Help Us Connect With Nature?
post_description: Humans are a conflicted species. Orbiting our tiny blue planet are 170 million small particles and 29,000 larger chunks of debris from satellites and rocket fragments. There is so much junk out there that it’s currently obscuring the visibility of earth from space. The irony is that most of these objects were launched to study the earth and keep an eye on it.

title: 8 Books for a Sustainable Mind
post_description: Over the past twelve months, publishers across the globe have produced groundbreaking books that improved our understanding of the need to live more sustainably on the planet. From bees to trees to the urban jungle, these standout books from 2016 will challenge you to think differently.

title: Is Healthy, Vibrant Soil a Solution for Climate Change?
post_description: There are many people waking up to the fact that climate change is a fundamental threat to humanity, and with that awakening is a rising sense of panic. How do we not only stop its advance, but also repair the damage? The solution may be as simple as understanding the critical role of an amazing substance right beneath our feet: soil.

title: Why Now is the Best Time to Go Solar
post_description: Have you considered solar for your home but assumed it was too expensive? Or are you waiting until the technology improves and the cost goes down? If so, wait no longer: now is the time to jump on the solar bandwagon. Technology has advanced markedly, and as more people have seen the wisdom of installing solar electric panels on their homes, economies of scale and efficiencies in manufacturing have brought the price down by more than 70% since 2009.

title: This Breakthrough Deal Brings New Hope to the Climate Fight
post_description: In the ongoing battle against climate change the world will be judged on the success of political maneuvering to prevent the impending global temperature rise. And while we’ve all been distracted by the unfolding election drama, a relatively quiet meeting in Kigali, Rwanda, may have been the most important development yet in our fight to rein in the planet’s warming temperatures.

title: Blueprint for a Greener Economy
post_description: We generally take the linear model of production -- where humans “take, make and dispose” --for granted. This model is a relatively recent creation of the Industrial Revolution. With a far smaller world population and vast tracts of sparsely inhabited land, the eighteenth century saw the environment as possessing near limitless ability to absorb the waste products of modernity.

title: Is Artificial Turf Safe for Athletes?
post_description: When Monsanto debuted “Chemgrass” in the plastic-loving ‘60s, what came to be known as Astroturf after the Astros installed it in their new stadium seemed to solve numerous problems.

title: The Paris Agreement: Saving the Chance to Save the Planet
post_description: Earlier this month, negotiators from 195 nations met in Paris for nearly two weeks at the 21st Conference of Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, commonly called COP21. The document they drafted in overtime, the Paris Agreement, lays out a legally-binding framework for addressing climate change for nations that ratify it.

title: Recent Environmental Wins Spur Hope
post_description: After years of frustrating struggle, a newly-invigorated environmental movement is gaining some serious momentum in its efforts to protect the climate. Everyday more concerned citizens join the fight for a livable future, contesting fossil fuel companies’ continued climate-warming extraction. Leaders at long last seem to be waking up to the fact that there’s no more time to delay and are acting in ways that would have seemed impossible just a few years ago.

title: This Changes Everything: Naomi Klein
post_description: Even dedicated subscribers to environmental newsfeeds can have trouble seeing the climate change forest for the trees. We pick up snippets on the California drought or the most recent superstorm, but the climate change big picture can easily elude us. Reading a hefty book synthesizing years of research, on the other hand, permits a deeper appreciation for the scope and complexities of climate science and policy.

title: Should we be Planting GM Trees?
post_description: Imagine a poplar tree that smells like roses, a virus-resistant fruit tree whose fruit won’t turn brown when sliced, a Eucalyptus tree which can withstand freezing, a lignin-free Loblolly pine easily processed into paper products, a chestnut tree invulnerable to blight…These beneficial properties are examples taken from dozens of experimental applications of genetic modification technologies.

title: The World Needs More Vegetarians. Is Fake Meat the Answer?
post_description: Do you have a burger habit you’d like to kick? The latest developments in plant-based meat alternatives may help. Nine billion people are expected to populate the earth by midcentury, posing a tremendous challenge to our current food systems.

title: New Slow City: Interview with Author William Powers
post_description: Can you imagine downsizing your home to live somewhere 80% smaller than where you live now? How about committing to work 24/7, but here’s the catch, 24/7 means that you work only 24 hours a week for seven months of the year? Sound impossible? Now imagine doing just that in the fastest city in the world, New York City.

title: The Ecological Benefits of Forest Fires
post_description: This has been the summer of forest fires in North America. Hundreds of fires still rage across the US and Canada as fire season winds down. To the thousands of people who have suffered loss of homes and property, there is no silver lining to a forest fire.

title: Community Solar Gardens: A Bright Idea Whose Time Has Come
post_description: Solar panels have become an increasingly common sight on buildings around the world, spurred on by rapidly falling prices, government incentives, and forward-thinking legislation. Perhaps you’ve looked into getting solar yourself and learned that you live under one of the millions of roofs not well-suited to producing solar power. Maybe you rent, maybe there’s too much shade, or maybe the upfront cost of installation is prohibitive.

title: Microbeads: The Smallest Ingredient in our Plastic Soup
post_description: Would you knowingly poison fish and other marine life in order to have whiter teeth and softer skin?  Would you risk poisoning yourself as well?  Believe it or not, that is what you are doing when you buy products that have microbeads in them.

title: If Ogunquit Can Quit Pesticides, So Can We
post_description: The fish, birds and animals who make their home in the Ogunquit River watershed can propose a toast with a clean, cool drink of water: the Maine town of Ogunquit has overwhelmingly passed a total ban on lawn pesticides.  Neither public nor private lands can be treated with the widely used toxic chemicals, some of which are known carcinogens, endocrine disrupters, and/or neurotoxins.  Ogunquit is the second US municipality to pass such a prohibition, the first being Takoma Park, Maryland, in 2013.

title: Does Coal Have a Future? These Countries Don't Think So
post_description: In the wake of the Paris agreement’s ratification by 129 of 197 participating nations, countries around the world have begun to move toward a less carbon-intensive future. One key way these countries seek to meet their climate commitments is by phasing out coal, one of the dirtiest sources of energy, responsible for about a quarter of global greenhouse gas emissions.

title: If Survival is the Question, Trees are the Answer
post_description: Trees. They breathe and store carbon dioxide, then give off oxygen, which we breathe. A vital fact, but that is not all, because as well as supplying our oxygen, and keeping our carbon levels in check, trees also regulate our planet’s water cycle, global temperatures and winds, and the cycles of positive and negative ions that govern our atmosphere, all these attributes crucial to the regulation of Earth’s temperatures, precipitation and winds.

title: How to Get Started with Alternative Energy
post_description: Renewable resources are on the rise in the US, with solar and wind power among the top four sources for new power capacity in 2013.  In Texas, solar and wind generators are now outbidding fossil fuel plants to provide cheap and reliable electricity.

title: Understanding Fracking's Massive Water Use
post_description: There are many luxuries that Americans have become accustomed to, but clean drinking water shouldn't be thought of as one of them. For centuries people have enjoyed drinking fresh water from a well or stream. But now it seems some will have to choose between energy in their homes or clean water from the tap—all thanks to fracking.

title: Hybrid Cars Going Mainstream, Sales Up 40%
post_description: A recent study by Experian Automotive reports that 40% more hybrid cars were sold in the U.S. in 2012 than in the previous year. And while hybrids claim just 3% of the auto market share, their steady rise in popularity has made them a mainstream choice among today’s car buyers. The growing popularity of hybrid cars is due to an increase in model choices, time-tested technology and more competitive pricing.

title: Bees Guided by Flowers’ Electric Fields
post_description: Bumblebees foraging for nectar favor those flowering plants which offer the best return on effort. The bees use certain floral cues to recognize these plants, such as the color and shape of its flowers, the floral pattern and its fragrance. But new research indicates that bumblebees  can also detect a flower’s electric field, exhibiting a level of communication far more complex than previously understood.

title: Food Fraud on the Rise
post_description: Since the dawn of commerce there has been an element of misinformation, hucksterism and downright fraud associated with many products on the consumer market. Where money is to be made, scruples have a way of being stretched thin. Years ago, ‘snake-oil’ salesmen made their livings pushing bogus elixirs on the gullible, and these practices led to the development of product regulation, oversight and consumer protection.

title: Carbon Reduction Efforts Failing to Thwart ‘4-degree’ Climate Doomsday Scenario
post_description: In spite of all the talk about reducing global carbon emissions during the Rio and Kyoto summits, countries are failing to reach stated carbon reduction goals. In fact, according to a new report by the United Nations Environment Program, there is today about 20% more carbon in the atmosphere since 2000.

title: Coral Reefs Communicate with Fish for Protection
post_description: Coral reefs are critical habitats for many species lower down on the marine food chain, and thus play a vital role in the health of all marine species. With the loss of over 50% of the Great Barrier coral since 1980, and the loss of 80% of living coral in the Caribbean, scientists have been studying reef interactions in hopes of finding ways to slow down and hopefully reverse this decline.

title: Arctic Sea Ice in Record Retreat
post_description: The prophecies are coming true. Not the ancient musings of religious scribes, and certainly not the constrained visions of our political leaders, but the cautious warnings of our scientists which have been largely ignored or disparaged for the inconvenience of their message. Recent satellite photos of the Arctic sea ice reveal an undeniable reality: our planet is warming at an alarmingly rapid pace, evidenced by an accelerating rate of sea ice decline.

title: Largest Dam Removal Project in US History Nears Completion
post_description: For the first time in over a century, newly hatched salmon fry are swimming in a stretch of the Elwha River formerly blocked to salmon runs by the Elwha and Glines Canyon dams. These small Coho fry represent a large success in the effort to restore rivers</br> to their natural flow.

title: New Studies Find Pesticide a Cause of Bee Colony Collapse
post_description: The global decline in bee colony populations may be due in large part to the widespread use of a common class of pesticide called “neonicotinoids”, according to two recent studies. Exposure to these substances, while not directly lethal to bees, may result in disorientation, loss of vitality and failure to produce queens among resident bee populations.

title: Is Coal Going the Way of the Dinosaur?
post_description: March 27, 2012: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced today its intention to enact strict regulations for allowable carbon emissions from new power plants. Dubbed the New Source Performance Standard, this measure may herald the dawn of a new era in clean energy generation, while hastening the demise of traditional coal-fired energy plants.

title: Ocean Acidification Accelerates, Threatening Marine Ecosystems
post_description: Since the dawn of life on Earth, ecosystems have evolved in accordance with prevailing climate conditions. When climate conditions change, organisms within ecosystems either adapt or become extinct. In the past century, the conditions affecting vital marine organisms have changed markedly, and the accelerating pace of this change does not favor the process of adaptation.

title: Biomimicry Mimicked
post_description: Adaptations mark the waypoints of evolution, as every living being incrementally morphs into forms most successful for survival.  Every flower, fish, animal and human has, over countless years, developed its unique formula to find nourishment, attract a mate, and protect their young while evading predatory threats. But every so often, one species notices the strategic advantage another species possesses, and strives to borrow some of that success by becoming a copycat, a mimic.

title: Apocalypse Not
post_description: The turn of a year, from old to new, is a special moment in time when optimism comes naturally.  Last year’s successes and failures are behind us, and we can look to the year ahead as a clean slate, and plan our lives to move closer to our personal goals. Every new year brings the future one year closer, and sharpens our view of the challenges which lie ahead of us.

title: 7 Ways Organic Farms Outperform Conventional Farms
post_description: Just a few generations ago, approximately 45% of Americans lived on farms. This demographic gradually but steadily declined as people migrated to urban centers, and over time, to suburbs. Today, only about 960,000 people claim farming as their principal occupation, which represents less than 1% of the US population.

title: New Facebook App Promotes Energy Saving through Social Networking
post_description: How much energy we consume as individuals and families has long been a private matter. Friends are really not that interested in how much energy we each consume, and in fact the topic rarely comes up for discussion in social circles. In fact, many of us are not even aware of our own energy footprints – we just pay the bills as they arrive.

title: LED Bulbs Are Ready to Light Your Home: 7 Tips You Should Know
post_description: The technological advances in the development of LED light bulbs have been fast and furious, with manufacturers competing to design LED bulbs suitable for every application in the home, while working to lower the retail price to a tipping point of mass consumer acceptance.

title: Amazing Display by Rescued Whale
post_description: While monitoring humpback whale activity in Mexico’s Sea of Cortez, researchers came across a young humbpack whale caught in fishnet. After hours of effort to release the whale, the last strands of net were finally cut.

title: Perennial Crops Being Developed to Produce Food with Less Environmental Impact
post_description: The amber waves of grain stretching across the heartland present an image of bounty, a promise of food for a hungry nation.

title: How Can Record Snowfalls Be Caused by Global Warming?
post_description: In New England, roofs have been collapsing due to extraordinary snowfall amounts, as freezing weather delayed melting, and snow accumulations increased to the breaking point in some structures. Across the US this winter, we’ve seen a succession of heavy snowfalls blanketing large regions, causing airport and highway closures. In December 2009, North America’s heaviest blizzard in a decade caused power outages and travel chaos along the eastern seaboard. The last two winters have also seen record snowfall amounts in Europe.

title: Pumping Ions: Gyms Generate Clean Energy From Muscle Power
post_description: A generation ago, gyms were the sole domain of boxers and bodybuilders, a very small slice of the urban demographic. Today, every urban micro-community has several gyms, with an array of workout equipment catering to men and women of all ages, pedaling, pumping and stretching their way to better personal fitness. In the near future, this wealth of expended energy will be harnessed, stored and recycled to power gyms sustainably.

title: If We Save the Tigers, We’ll Save the Planet
post_description: Tigers have long provoked awe in the human imagination, becoming symbols of untamed nature whose "fearful symmetry," in the words of William Blake, has inspired everything from art to advertising. In the wild, however, tigers are on the verge of disappearing.

title: Supersize Ships Being Built to Feed Our Consumer Appetites
post_description: Walmart is betting heavily that consumer demand for goods made in China will remain strong for many years to come. The Emma Maersk, shown in these photos, was launched as the third of a planned fleet of five new “supersize” cargo ships, designed to transport goods across the Pacific in just 5 days. Two more ships are commissioned to be completed in 2012.

title: Cheap 'Teabag' Water Filter Could Save Millions
post_description: A cheap and effective filtering device developed by a South African university could provide safe drinking water to millions of people, drastically reducing the incidence of waterborne illnesses such as cholera and other diarrheal diseases.

title: Solar Power from Water-Based ‘Artificial Leaves’
post_description: A team of US and Korean scientists have invented water-based ‘artificial leaves’ that can act like solar cells to produce electricity. The flexible devices have the potential to be less expensive and more environmentally friendly than standard silicon-based solar cells, said the researchers.

title: Google Hits the Road with a Self-Driving Prius
post_description: Next generation drivers may feel like chauffeur driven celebrities, enjoying the freedom of driving without the responsibility. Aspiring drivers may never face the dreaded ‘road test’, and road ragers of the future may have no one to rage at.

title: Fish Farms That Mimic Nature
post_description: Worldwide demand for seafood has increased by nearly 50 times since the 1950’s and continues to grow. With approximately three-quarters of the world’s fisheries fully exploited or depleted, the dependence on farm-grown seafood has steadily increased. In fact, for the first time this year, more fish consumed in the world will be farmed rather than caught in the wild. The vast majority of salmon and shrimp consumed in the U.S., for example, is sourced from fish farms in Asia.

title: Human-Electric Hybrid Car Available in 2011
post_description: The hand-cranked low mass vehicle (LMV) was developed by engineer Professor Charles Samuel Greenwood, who has been working on human-powered vehicles for over four decades, and has now developed a street legal sedan version carrying four people. If the four people are all cranking, the vehicle can run solely on human power, but it is also an electric plug-in.

title: 6 Ways Mushrooms Can Save the World
post_description: In this TED talk video, mycologist Paul Stamets talks about mushrooms. He believes there are six ways that mycelium fungus can save our planet. This brief presentation is not only fascinating, but a reminder of why it is so important to preserve unique species and critical habits within ecosystems.

title: New Automotive Fuel-Efficiency Standards Set for US, Canada
post_description: US regulators on Thursday finalized new fuel efficiency rules for cars and light trucks, raising fuel economy standards and for the first time regulating greenhouse-gas emissions blamed for global warming.

title: Solar Energy From the Rajasthan Desert Can Meet India’s Future Power Needs
post_description: Solar energy is an enormous resource that is readily available in all countries throughout the world, and all the space above the earth.  Long ago scientists calculated that an hour’s worth of sunlight bathing the planet held far more energy than humans worldwide could consume in a year.

title: Bloom Box: A Breakthrough in Clean, Green Energy?
post_description: Bloom Energy, based in Sunnyvale, California, is about to launch a public release of its “power plant in a box”, which it hopes will revolutionize the way energy is produced, stored and transmitted. Dubbed the ‘Bloom Box’, this device uses fuel-cell technology which mixes oxygen with fuel to produce electricity with no burning, no combustion and no power lines.

title: Solar Power From Saharan Sun Could Power Europe
post_description: Harnessing a small part of the intense power of the Sahara sun with a giant network of solar panels has the potential to provide clean energy to Europe while significantly reducing carbon emissions, and experts at the European Climate Forum and the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, are considering the viability of such a plan.

title: The End of the Line: A Future Without Fish?
post_description: The End of the Line is a documentary film by Rupert Murray, based on the investigative journalism of Charles Clover, the former UK Telegraph environment editor whose 2005 book of the same name exposed the plight of the world’s oceans due to overfishing, wasteful fishing methods and the ever-increasing consumer demand for seafood.

title: Juicy and Tender, Seitan is Quite Possibly the Best Fake Meat - But There is a Downside
post_description: What if the next big thing to revolutionize the lives of vegans and vegetarians was waiting in the wings? What if this next big thing was amazingly high in protein, amazingly low in fat and carbs, relatively low in sodium, and cholesterol-free, yet with a taste and texture more like real meat than any other analogue ever devised? What if the next big thing was chewy and exuded meaty juices and sometimes even required a knife to cut?

title: World’s First Solar Airplane, Solar Impulse, Ready to Fly
post_description: The Solar Impulse aircraft, officially known as HB-SIA, successfully underwent its first engine run up last week at an airbase near Zurich in Switzerland, and travelled over 2km across a runway yesterday in a critical pre-flight test which clears the way for airborne trials in February 2010. It is designed to make the first solar-powered flight around the world.

title: Tree Fungus Found to Produce Diesel
post_description: Gary Strobel, a plant pathologist at Montana State University, Bozeman, and colleagues report that Gliocladium roseum, a fungus found in rainforest trees, produces dozens of the same hydrocarbons found in gasoline, diesel fuel, and jet fuel. The fungus may help companies convert the chemical energy stored in plants into liquid fuels capable of replacing fossil fuels.

title: Hydrogen - Fuel of the Future?
post_description: Imagine a future where the electrical power needed to run your computer, TV, and DVD is generated from a small appliance about the size of a dishwasher located in your home. Envision generating electricity without combustion, and producing heat and pure drinking water as by-products.

title: Carbon Offsets
post_description: A “carbon offset” is an emission reduction credit which can be purchased by individuals, businesses and governments to reduce their net greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.

title: Back to School with Sustainability in Mind
post_description: The back-to-school supply list can be bewildering enough on its own, but throw in environmental considerations, and you may find your head spinning. Don’t despair -- below are some strategies for limiting the eco-impact of sending kids back to school.

title: 15 Ways to Help Your Community Garden Thrive
post_description: Always on the go helping people create and enjoy community gardens, Master Gardener Natalie Walsh is busy as a bee. We're grateful she's paused a moment to share with us some of her gardening and community-building ideas.

title: How to Campaign for a Less Plastic Planet
post_description: You’ve heard about the problems with plastic. But what can you do about it? Getting active is easier than you think.

title: 5 Must-Read Non-Fiction Books from 2018
post_description: Compiling a list of reading favorites is always a challenge. Since there’s no book that suits every reader, there’s no ‘best book’ list that meets everyone’s criteria. Thankfully this year’s picks share the essential elements of a cracking good read: they inform, entertain, and—dare we say it—expand the mind.

title: School Gardens: Can They Make Our Children Smarter?
post_description: When a soccer ball lands in the garden, flattening a stand of newly sprouted peas, or an overzealous weeder pulls out a row of seedlings by mistake, many gardeners would be tempted to scream. After all, growing food is hard work. When something sets you back, isn’t that a negative thing?

title: 5 Back-to-School Breakfast Bowl Recipes to Make Your Mornings Easier
post_description: It’s that time of year again, when kids across the country get ready to go back to school and extra-curricular activities—and their parents wonder how they’re going to fit it all in. Enter Laura Keogh and Ceri Marsh, former magazine-editors-turned-food-bloggers whose indispensible book, The School Year Survival Cookbook, offers welcome strategies for time-strapped families looking to put healthy food on the table (and in the lunchbox).

title: Food Deserts: How Important is Your Neighborhood Grocery Store?
post_description: According to recent statistics, in the U.S. alone an estimated 23 million people live in what are known as food deserts. The term has gained popularity as a way to refer to areas where residents lack access to healthy food options, especially produce. People in these areas often live below the poverty line, don’t own cars, and don’t have a grocery store within walking distance.

title: How Urban Farming is Healing Lives in Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside
post_description: Walking down Main Street in Vancouver, British Columbia, you will be surrounded by crumbling buildings, bars, and a prominent population of homeless people occupying door stoops.

title: Why Your Employer Should be Part of the Sustainability Solution
post_description: Everyone knows how hard it can be to replace an undesirable habit with a good one. Habits take time to form, and they can take just as long to break. According to Psychology Today, people often fail to break unwanted habits because their goals aren’t specific enough, or they haven’t truly faced up to the fact that change is difficult.

title: Why Your Drop in the Bucket Leads to a Powerful Splash
post_description: You would never know that Gary Rosenberg’s home in Berkeley, California, was once an abandoned crack house without a stitch of greenery. Today the brightly painted house is surrounded by lush edibles—apricots, figs, limes, and berries—along with an impressive array of alternative energy and waste reduction projects.

title: Gifts from Recycled Materials
post_description: We carefully curated the following list to include items that divert materials from the waste stream and use them again for practical purposes. These products are made by individuals and small businesses who are trying to make a difference.

title: The Fixer Movement Makes Old Things New Again
post_description: One day the comma button fell off my laptop. No matter how hard I tried to reattach it, nothing worked. I took my computer into my nearest business supply and computer shop and asked them to fix it for me.  The shop’s representative told me the only solution was to get a new computer.

title: The Enduring Legacy of 4-H
post_description: On a blustery fall day in the Pacific Northwest, my daughter is assessing an injury. Spreading the webbed foot of a domestic duck between her twelve-year-old fingers, she looks for telltale signs of inflammation in the crinkly, grey skin. The duck (otherwise known as Athena) has been limping for days, but she tolerates the inspection thanks to the vet-like hold my daughter uses to keep her wings secure.

title: The Benefits of Living in a Multi-Generational Household
post_description: Our fifty-year national experiment with nuclear families (the ideal of two parents, two-and-a-half kids, and the white picket fence) is ending. The old and faithful interdependence of extended family is reemerging as the cultural norm.

title: Does Your Child Need More Free Time?
post_description: As a child I lived in a rural area where the only thing to do during the summer was to spend time outside. A decrepit TV antenna bolted to our house provided little allure for those of us bent on excitement. Nothing was on but soap operas and news: boring.

title: How to Start a Neighborhood Tool Share
post_description: Do you have a garage, shed and/or workroom filled with tools you got for a project and then never needed again? Do you and all of your neighbors each have your own lawn mower, snow blower, leaf blower and extension ladders? That’s a lot of stuff, which takes up a lot of space, and costs quite a bit of money! Before you buy more equipment for your next house project, consider whether you might share with your neighbors.

title: Not Back-to-School
post_description: When Growing Without Schooling was first published in 1977, the revolutionary magazine represented a small fraction of children homeschooled in the United States and around the world. Since that time, the population of children who learn at home has grown, with rapid increases taking place in the last few decades. From 850,000 in 1999 to more than 2 million in 2010 in the U.S. alone, homeschooling is now a worldwide phenomenon.

title: The Giftless Birthday Party
post_description: The first time I attended a “giftless” birthday party I was visiting a friend whose youngest child was turning three. Excited children scampered about the yard, playing games and shrieking with delight as the water hose sprayed anyone in its path. A few songs and a birthday cake later, my friend’s youngest sister arrived with the highlight of the day: a cardboard box.

title: Elimination Communication - Does Your Baby Need Diapers?
post_description: ‘Natural infant hygiene’, ‘elimination communication’, ‘diaper free’: these are just a few of the names given to methods of early infant toileting around the world. From Asia to Africa to India, the Arctic, and Latin America, cultures across the globe embrace diaper-free living as early as the first week of life.

title: Should You Buy a Farm Share? 10 Reasons to Join Your Local CSA
post_description: Once a rarity, CSAs (short for community supported agriculture) and farm shares have taken off in the last decade. Why? Because CSAs offer a fantastic opportunity for both farmer and eater. Here’s how it works: Each season, CSA members pay a set fee for a “share” of the farmer’s harvest. The farmers have a guaranteed income, and members get piles of incredibly fresh produce</br> at a very affordable price.

title: Raising Kids in the Age of Environmental Guilt
post_description: When I saw the title of Paige Wolfe’s new book, Spit That Out! The Overly Informed Parent’s Guide to Raising Healthy Kids in the Age of Environmental Guilt, I jumped at the chance to read it. As an eco-conscious (and eco-anxious) parent of two young kids, those words spoke to me. I recoil almost daily at something my kids come in contact with or that some well-meaning grownup gives them to eat. You know what I’m talking about.

title: Creating Green Holiday Traditions
